data.title: Navigating Singapore’s Public Transport
data.meta_description: Explore Singapore public transport with our guide for Indians. Learn about MRT, buses, and taxis to navigate the city efficiently and affordably.
data.text:
Singapore public transport system is a modern marvel, connecting the vibrant city-state with utmost efficiency. Imagine traversing this stunning island nation, seamlessly hopping from one corner to another with ease. It’s a traveller’s dream come true!

A Singapore map provides a detailed overview of the city, helping you navigate its streets and locate key attractions. The backbone of this awe-inspiring system is the Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) network, boasting a web of train lines that crisscross the island, ensuring you reach your destination in a flash.

But that’s not all—buses, taxis, and even futuristic autonomous shuttles are at your service, providing an eco-friendly and comfortable commute across Singapore.

Let’s explore the world-class Singapore public transport network.

Travelling to Singapore? Read more about Singapore tourist visa requirements for Indians!

How to travel in Singapore? Singapore’s local bus service is an integral part of the city’s public transportation system. You’ll find single and double-decker buses operated by various companies, ensuring comprehensive city coverage. These air-conditioned buses are a cost-effective and comfortable way to get around Singapore.

How to Find the Bus Routes

Google Maps

Google Maps is a fantastic tool to discover bus routes in Singapore. Simply enter your start point and destination, select the public transit option, and Google Maps will provide you with detailed bus routes, bus numbers, and estimated arrival times. It’s user-friendly and updated with real-time information. You should consider getting the Singapore Travel Pass. It offers various options for tourists. The Singapore bus map illustrates the city’s extensive bus network, making it easier to plan your bus journeys within Singapore.

Tourist Information Centres

If you prefer a more traditional approach, visit tourist information centres in Singapore. They offer brochures, Singapore tourist maps, and are manned by knowledgeable staff who can guide you to the right bus routes. These centres are often located at popular tourist spots. For travelling, you can also get a Singapore metro pass.

Navigating Public Transport in Singapore With Other Useful Apps

Singabus: Singabus is a user-friendly app with real-time bus information and schedules. It’s your go-to guide for tracking bus arrivals and planning your routes across Singapore. Consider getting a Singapore metro pass, it’ll come in handy throughout your trip.

MyTransport: MyTransport is an official app by the Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore that provides various transport-related services, including real-time bus arrivals, route planning, and even parking availability. Singapore public transport fares are based on the distance travelled, and you can use stored-value cards or passes for convenience.

SG Dr Bus: SG Dr Bus is a reliable app for comprehensive bus and MRT information, including schedules and real-time updates. It’s a handy tool for daily commuters. Look for “How much should I budget for a trip to Singapore” when going for the first time. The Singapore MRT map is a valuable resource for navigating the city’s MRT lines and stations for a convenient trip within Singapore.

SG BusLeh: SG BusLeh is an app that can help you navigate public transport in Singapore with ease. It offers route planning, real-time bus arrival information, and more.

Bus Uncle: Bus Uncle is a fun and informative app that offers real-time bus information with a quirky twist. It’s perfect for those who appreciate a touch of humour with their commute.

Citymapper: Citymapper is a global transit app known for its detailed public transport information. It covers the bus, MRT, and more, making it an excellent choice for both locals and tourists.

The distance you travel determines the Singapore bus fare. You have several options to pay for a bus ride in Singapore:

Singapore Tourist Pass: The Singapore Tourist Pass offers tourists unlimited travel on public buses, MRT, and LRT trains. It’s a convenient card designed for visitors to explore Singapore without worrying about fares. You can purchase it for a specific duration. Singapore travel cards will benefit you in your travel experience.

Adult Stored-Value Smartcard: Adult stored-value smartcards like EZ-Link or NETS FlashPay are prepaid cards that allow you to pay for buses and MRT rides. Simply top up the card and tap it when boarding; the fare is deducted from the card’s balance.

International Mastercard® and Visa contactless bank cards: If you have an international Mastercard or Visa contactless bank card, you can use it for payments on Singapore’s public transportation. Tap your card when boarding and alighting; the fare is automatically deducted. If your card is linked to your smartphone or smartwatch, you can tap to pay with those too! The Singapore Train Pass offers unlimited rides on public buses and also on the MRT, providing an efficient way to explore the city’s transportation system.

Cash: You can pay in cash when boarding a bus. However, having the exact fare is crucial as drivers may not provide change. Drop coins or notes into the cash box, and the driver will issue a ticket. This option is less common with the rise of contactless payment methods.

Which cities have convenient modes of transportation in Singapore?

Here are some of the most vibrant neighbourhoods and hubs in Singapore where you can explore various transportation options and experience the city’s rich cultural diversity with ease:

Suntec City: This is a bustling commercial and entertainment hub known for the iconic Suntec City Mall. It’s a convenient transportation hub where you can access various public transport options, including buses and the Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system. Suntec City is well-connected, making it easy to explore Singapore affordably using public transportation.

Chinatown: As one of Singapore’s most culturally significant neighbourhoods, Chinatown offers a unique blend of history and modernity. Here, you can explore the rich heritage, enjoy delicious street food, and immerse yourself in the vibrant atmosphere. When it comes to transportation, Chinatown is well-served by MRT stations, making it easy to navigate the city. For a better idea, look at the Singapore tourist map.

Little India: This colourful neighbourhood is a sensory delight with its vibrant streets, temples, and authentic Indian cuisine. It’s also a great place to experience Singapore’s public transportation system, with MRT stations nearby and buses that connect you to various parts of the city.

Kampong Glam: Kampong Glam is known for its Malay and Arab cultural heritage, with stunning mosques, trendy shops, and cosy cafes. You’ll find MRT stations and buses nearby to explore the city and its cultural richness.

Clarke Quay: The riverside Clarke Quay is famous for its lively nightlife, dining, and entertainment options. It’s well-connected by public transportation with nearby MRT stations making it easy to get around and enjoy the city’s nightlife without breaking the bank.

How to Buy Tickets?

In Singapore, there are several convenient ways to pay for a bus ride:

You can use your credit or debit card to make payments for bus rides. These cards should have contactless payment technology, indicated by the contactless symbol.

The SimplyGo system allows you to use your EZ-Link card for bus rides. These are contactless stored-value cards.

Purchase a NETS prepaid card and top it up with the desired amount. Then, tap the card on the reader when boarding the bus to pay for your ride.

Load credit onto your card and tap it on the reader when boarding the bus to pay for your journey. The “Singapore to KL bus” route is a common and convenient option for travellers looking to journey from Singapore to Kuala Lumpur (KL), offering an affordable and hassle-free means of reaching Malaysia’s vibrant capital.

Concession cards are available for specific groups, such as students and senior citizens.

These cards offer discounted fares for eligible individuals. Tap the card on the reader when boarding the bus to use them.

Here’s a quick rundown of the cost of tickets for public transport in Singapore:

Singapore MRT fares for Standard Ticket (Cash Fares):

For distances between 0.0–3.2 km: SGD 1.40 (~₹87 )

For distances between 3.3–6.2 km: SGD 1.60 (~₹99)

For distances between 6.3–8.2 km: SGD 1.80 (~₹110)

Singapore MRT price for Express and Fast Forward Services (Cash Fares):

For distances between 0.0–8.2 km: SGD 2.20 (~₹136)

For distances between 8.3–11.2 km: SGD 2.35 (~₹140)

For distances between 11.3–15.2 km: SGD 2.50 (~₹150)

Singapore MRT fares for EZ-Link Card (Card Payments):

For distances between 0.0–3.2 km: SGD 0.77 (~₹50)

For distances between 3.3–6.2 km: SGD 0.87-1.07 (~₹70)

For distances between 6.3–8.2 km: SGD 1.16-1.23 (~₹80)

Singapore MRT price for Express and Fast Forward Services (Card Payments):

For distances between 0.0–8.2 km: SGD 1.37-1.83 (~₹110)

For distances between 8.3–11.2 km: SGD 1.89-1.97 (~₹120)

For distances between 11.3–15.2 km: SGD 2.01-2.13 (~₹130)

These fares and Singapore travel passes offer flexibility for getting around Singapore’s public transportation network, making it easy for both residents and tourists to travel conveniently and affordably.

Popular Attractions You Can Visit through Singapore MRT

While there are numerous attractions in Singapore accessible through the Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system, you can easily explore the city and visit these popular destinations starting from Changi Airport:

Gardens by the Bay: Take the East-West Line from Changi Airport to Tanah Merah, then transfer to the Downtown Line and alight at Bayfront MRT station. This will lead you to the iconic Gardens by the Bay and its magnificent Supertree Grove. You can also check the Singapore tourist pass price online and get one for free access to both public transport as well as the special domes inside the Gardens by the Bay.

Marina Bay Sands: Continue on the Downtown Line to Downtown MRT station to reach Marina Bay Sands, an architectural marvel with a rooftop pool and stunning city views.

Esplanade -Theatres on the Bay: Located near City Hall MRT station (East-West Line), the Esplanade is a hub for arts and culture, offering concerts and performances.

Merlion Park: A short walk from Raffles Place MRT station (East-West Line) brings you to Merlion Park, where you can see the famous Merlion statue and enjoy beautiful waterfront views.

Chinatown: Take the North-East Line from Raffles Place to Chinatown MRT station, where you can explore the bustling streets, temples, and markets.

Routes and Stations

In Singapore, the public transportation system is well-developed and easily accessible on Google Maps. Singapore’s MRT map can help you get a better understanding of popular tourist attractions near stations and help you navigate the country well. You can typically use Google Maps to plan routes and view stations for the Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) stations, buses, and more. To check the visibility of routes and stations, follow these steps:

Open Google Maps on your device.

Enter your starting point, which could be a landmark in the heart of the city.

Enter your destination, which should be another landmark a few kilometres apart.

Click on the public transport (bus) icon to see the routes and stations available.

There are certain tips that you must keep in mind when you are travelling in Singapore public transport:

Operating Timings: The MRT system in Singapore typically operates from early morning to late at night. The first train usually starts running around 6:00 am, and the last train departs around midnight. The Singapore train map shows both MRT (Mass Rapid Transit) and LRT (Light Rail Transit) networks, to help travellers in understanding the rail system’s routes – this includes the airport line that connects the Changi International Airport with Singapore city.

Wheelchair-friendly: Singapore’s MRT is wheelchair-friendly. Many train carriages feature designated spaces for wheelchairs and mobility devices. Also, you can check online for a better idea about the Singapore train ticket price.

Etiquette: When travelling on the MRT, follow common etiquette, which includes allowing other passengers to exit before you board, offering your seat to those in need and maintaining a quiet and respectful environment.

Travelling with Stroller or Kids: If you’re travelling with a stroller or children, it’s advisable to avoid peak hours when the trains are crowded, typically on weekdays during the morning (around 7-8 am) and evening (around 5:30 pm) rush hours.

Popular Bicycle Paths

Singapore Round Island Loop: This scenic route takes you around the entire island so you can experience diverse landscapes, from urban to coastal.

Mandai Loop: Explore the Mandai area with lush greenery, wildlife, and serene reservoirs on this nature-inspired trail.

Mount Faber Loop: Ride to Mount Faber to enjoy panoramic city views, and descend through lush greenery for a diverse cycling experience.

Seletar Loop: Experience the tranquillity of Seletar as you cycle through charming neighbourhoods and along the reservoir.

St. John’s & Lazarus Island: A coastal adventure to two pristine islands with beautiful beaches and a relaxed, island-hopping vibe.

Cost of Hiring Cycles

Hiring cycles in Singapore is quite affordable. You can find a variety of bikes, including adult bikes, children’s bikes, and even mountain bikes. The typical rental rate ranges from SGD 6 (~₹300) to SGD 10 (~₹600) per hour.

Guidelines for Cycling in Singapore

Here are some guidelines for cycling in Singapore:

Cyclists must obey all traffic signals and travel in the same direction as the flow of traffic.

It’s advisable to wear a helmet when cycling on the roads for safety.

Always keep to the left-hand edge of roads, and ride in a single file on single-lane roads.

Cyclists should ride in groups of no more than five bicycles in length.

While there isn’t a specific speed limit for cyclists, it’s essential to maintain a safe and reasonable speed.

Best Time to Walk/Cycle

Early Morning: Starting your walk or bike ride in the early morning, around 6 am to 8 am, allows you to enjoy cooler temperatures and lower humidity. It’s a refreshing way to begin the day.

Late Afternoon: In the late afternoon, from 4 pm to 6 pm, the weather begins to cool down, making it a pleasant time for outdoor activities. Plus, you can catch the beautiful sunset.

Avoid Midday: Singapore can get very hot and humid in the midday sun, making it less comfortable for walking or cycling. It’s best to avoid the hours between 11 am and 3 pm.

Weekends: Weekends are great for outdoor activities because you have more time to explore without rushing. Popular spots like East Coast Park and Sentosa are often bustling with cyclists and pedestrians on weekends.

Jaywalking is Illegal

Jaywalking in Singapore has been illegal since 1977. Offenders can face fines ranging from USD 20 to USD 2,000 (INR ₹20,000-₹16 lakh) or even imprisonment for up to 6 months. This strict law aims to ensure pedestrian safety and maintain smooth traffic flow. Crossing the road outside designated crossing zones is a serious offence, emphasising the importance of following traffic regulations in the city-state. So, when in Singapore, it’s essential to use pedestrian crossings and obey traffic signals to avoid penalties.
